message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about soil composition and the role of different organisms in soil health. Adding fungi to the soil can increase the amount of organic matter because fungi have the ability to break down organic materials and convert them into nutrients that can be used by plants. Option (B) is incorrect because while sunflowers may contribute to soil health by providing organic matter when they decompose, they do not directly increase the amount of organic matter in the soil. Option (C) is partially correct because trees can contribute to soil health by shedding leaves and branches which provide organic matter, but they do not directly increase the amount of organic matter in the soil. Option (D) is incorrect because voles are small mammals and do not contribute to organic matter in the soil.

This question requires knowledge about organic matter and its contribution to soil fertility. Fungi are a type of microorganism that decompose organic matter, such as dead plants and animals, and contribute to the natural recycling of nutrients in the soil. Adding fungi to the soil can help increase the amount of organic matter, which in turn improves soil structure, water retention, and nutrient availability. Option (B) is incorrect because sunflowers are a type of plant and not directly related to increasing organic matter in soil. Option (C) is also incorrect because while trees contribute to organic matter when they decompose, they do not directly increase the amount of organic matter in the soil. Option (D) is unrelated and not related to increasing organic matter in soil.

This question requires knowledge about organic matter and its role in soil health. Adding fungi to the soil can naturally increase the amount of organic matter because fungi are decomposers. They break down dead plant material and recycle nutrients back into the soil. Options (B), (C), and (D) are not directly related to increasing organic matter in the soil. Sunflowers and trees can contribute to soil health by providing organic matter when their leaves and plant parts decompose, but they are not the best answer in this context. Voles, small rodents, do not directly contribute to increasing organic matter in the soil.

This question requires basic knowledge about the role of organic matter in soil and how it can be increased. Organic matter in soil is typically composed of decomposed plant and animal material. Fungi play a crucial role in breaking down this organic material and converting it into nutrients that can be utilized by plants. Therefore, adding fungi to soil can help increase the amount of organic matter present. Option (B) is incorrect because sunflowers are plants and not organisms that contribute directly to organic matter. Option (C) is partially correct because trees can contribute to organic matter through their fallen leaves, but without the presence of decomposer organisms like fungi, this organic matter may not break down completely. Option (D) is incorrect because voles are small rodents and do not directly contribute to organic matter in soil.

This question requires knowledge about the role of organisms in increasing organic matter in soil. Fungi are decomposers that break down organic materials and contribute to the formation of humus, which is an important component of soil organic matter. Option (B) is incorrect because sunflowers are plants and do not directly increase organic matter in soil. Option (C) is partially correct because trees can contribute to organic matter in soil through the decomposition of their leaves and branches, but they do not directly increase organic matter. Option (D) is incorrect because voles are rodents and do not contribute to the increase of organic matter in soil.

This question requires knowledge about the role of organic matter in soil and how it can be increased naturally. Option (A) is correct because fungi, such as mycorrhizal fungi, break down organic matter and create humus, which is an important component of soil organic matter. This helps improve soil structure, water retention, and nutrient availability. Option (B) is incorrect because while sunflowers may have deep roots that can help break up compacted soil, they do not directly contribute to increasing organic matter. Option (C) is incorrect because trees can also help improve soil structure, but they do not directly contribute to increasing organic matter. Option (D) is incorrect because voles are small mammals and do not have a direct role in adding organic matter to soil.

This question requires knowledge about the role of different organisms in soil health. Adding fungi to soil can increase the amount of organic matter. Fungi break down organic materials, such as dead plants and animals, and convert them into organic matter that can be used by other organisms in the soil. Option (B) is incorrect because while sunflowers can add biomass to the soil, they do not directly contribute to increasing organic matter. Option (C) is incorrect because while trees can contribute to soil health by providing organic matter through leaf litter and root decomposition, they do not directly increase the amount of organic matter. Option (D) is incorrect because voles are small rodents and do not contribute to increasing organic matter in soil.

To naturally increase the amount of organic matter in soil, adding fungi is the best option. Fungi plays a crucial role in the decomposition of organic matter. They break down dead plants and animals into smaller particles, releasing nutrients into the soil. This process helps to enrich the soil with organic matter, which improves its quality and fertility. Option (B) is incorrect because while sunflowers are plants that contribute to organic matter through their roots and decaying parts, they do not have the same direct impact as fungi. Option (C) is partially correct because trees can also contribute to organic matter, but they are not as efficient as fungi in breaking down material and enriching the soil. Option (D) is incorrect because voles are small mammals and do not directly contribute to the addition of organic matter in soil.

To naturally increase the amount of organic matter in soil, adding fungi is the best option. Fungi play a crucial role in the decomposition of organic matter. They break down dead plant material and organic waste, converting them into nutrients that can be absorbed by plants. This process is known as decomposition, and it helps to enrich the soil with organic matter. Option (B) is incorrect because sunflowers are not involved in decomposition and do not contribute to increasing organic matter in soil. Option (C) is also incorrect because while trees can contribute to organic matter through the falling of leaves and branches, they do not directly enhance decomposition. Option (D) is incorrect because voles are small rodents and do not have a direct impact on increasing organic matter in soil.
